abstract.p: Alan M Edelson letter questions claim that Tappan Zee Bridge, built in 1955, has to be replaced; observes that Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges, opened in 1883 and 1903 respectively, are still in service, as is 1930 George Washington Bridge (S)

block.p: It is puzzling to read that a study of the Tappan Zee Bridge finds that it is too costly to repair and must be replaced (news article, Jan. 12). It was completed in 1955. The Brooklyn and Williamsburg Bridges were opened in 1883 and 1903, respectively. Several other major bridges to Manhattan are far older than the Tappan Zee Bridge. The George Washington Bridge, constructed in 1930, is not only still in service but also had a lower deck added to it in the early 1960's.

It is puzzling to read that a study of the Tappan Zee Bridge finds that it is too costly to repair and must be replaced (news article, Jan. 12). It was completed in 1955. The Brooklyn and Williamsburg Bridges were opened in 1883 and 1903, respectively. Several other major bridges to Manhattan are far older than the Tappan Zee Bridge. The George Washington Bridge, constructed in 1930, is not only still in service but also had a lower deck added to it in the early 1960's.

Was something flawed in the design or construction of the Tappan Zee Bridge? Or are we taxpayers being fed a dubious tale to justify construction of a new $4 billion bridge that will add more traffic delays in Westchester and Rockland Counties?
ALAN M. EDELSON Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y. Jan. 12, 2000
